basics.name: Tanish Baranwal
basics.label: Undergraduate Student
basics.summary: An undergraduate student interested in pursuing a PhD in pushing the capabilities of Artificial Intelligence. Although I am exploring several niches, I am passionate about exploring the extent of which AI can solve real-world problems and am currently interested in Large Multi-Modal Models and Complex Planning.

work.name: Cardiac Vision Labs, University of California, San Francisco
work.summary: Designed diffusion models for the generative modeling of cardiac excitation waves, achieving state-of-the-art results for imaging 3D wave dynamics, cardiac wave simulation, and parameter-specific initial condition generation to demonstrate that diffusion models have many potential applications in cardiac arrhythmia research and diagnostics
highlights: Presented Paper at Computing in Cardiology 2023
Presented Paper at 2024 SIAM Annual Meeting

work.name: eGolf.ai
work.summary: Designed an algorithm using Short-Time Fourier Transform, spectrogram analysis, and Convolutional Neural Networks to analyze golf swing data and predict statistics like impact position, ball spin, and carry. Applied RANSAC, Kalman Filtering, and Pose2Sim to calculate athlete poses from video and motion sensors

work.name: DomaniSystems Inc
work.summary: Designed a hybrid PCA-Autoencoder anomaly detection scheme to identify anomalies in mission-critical systems. Created a fault-tolerant IoT framework that combines a software-based “digital twin” and triple modular redundancy to improve the reliability of mission-critical systems without overly increasing the overall cost. Finetuned the mT5 large language model to be a multilingual chatbot that can respond in colloquial vernacular to improve a teaching app for learning East-Asian languages
highlights: Submitted paper to 2024 IEEE 10th World Forum on Internet of Things
Submitted paper to Journal of Modelling and Simulation in Engineering
Submitted paper to Journal of Electrical and Computer Engineering

work.name: Louis Lab, University of California, Santa Barbara
work.summary: Analyzed neurological differences in the locomotion of different species of the Drosophila larva and built a novel 95% accurate unsupervised behavior classifier to replace human annotators. Designed domain-specific locomotive features to train a supervised random forest algorithm to predict larval behavior modes from noisy human annotations to determine the larval decision process. Took the initiative to implement Q-learning and SARSA algorithms in MATLAB to identify differences in evolutionary circumstances that aided fellow researchers to speed up their research

work.name: Aspiring Scholars Directed Research Program
work.summary: Developed a retrosynthesis planning algorithm by screening molecules based on synthetic complexity calculated using a Gaussian Mixture Model based Autoencoder scheme. Discovered possible molecules that inhibit SARS-COV2, HIV and could act as SSRIs by identifying key chem-informatics descriptors through logistic regression-based feature importance analysis.
highlights: Two papers accepted at Journal of Emerging Investigators

courses: Intro to Computer Vision and Comp. Photography
